1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project proponent M/s. A.A. Energy Limited (AAEL) has installed a 10 MW biomass based
power generation project at Desaiganj Wadsa in Gadchiroli district of Maharashtra. The proposed
small scale project utilises the surplus biomass residues primarily from rice husk available locally
to generate power through sustainable means without causing any negative impacts on the
environment.

3.6 Methodology Deviations
1. Grid emission factor
The methodology refers to CDM Tool 7 for electricity grid emission factor. However, the data is
not available in public domain to calculate the grid emission factor and therefore project owner
is not able to calculate this factor.
The project owner request to use the publicly available grid emission factor for the project,
which will be fix for first crediting period. For future crediting period project owner anticipates
that the data will be available to calculate the grid emission factor and then the Tool 7 or any
other Verra guidance will be used for the project.
Based on publicly available information, the following data is available for UAE grid emission
factor:
The Project will consumed less electricity with respect to the baseline and therefore lower grid
emission factor will result in lower baseline emissions and lower emission reductions and
therefore the lower grid emission factor will be conservative of therefor lower value (IRENA) is
selected. As IRENA value is latest and conservative therefore this has been used for the first
crediting period.

model_answer:
The methodology of this project includes the following:

1. Grid emission factor: The project owner is unable to calculate the grid emission factor using publicly available data. They have requested to use a publicly available grid emission factor for the project, which will be fixed for the first crediting period. For future crediting periods, they anticipate having the data to calculate the grid emission factor and will use Tool 7 or other Verra guidance.

2. Benchmarking Boundary: The default benchmark boundary is the city where the project activity is located, which in this case is Abu Dhabi. The methodology considers Abu Dhabi Emirate as the city for methodological requirements and the benchmark boundary.

3. Baseline Emissions: Baseline emissions are estimated using Approach 1 as the benchmark installation is an electricity-driven technology. The calculation of total baseline emissions involves the use of Equation (1) from methodological tool 05, which includes parameters such as estimated electricity consumption, average technical transmission and distribution losses, and the grid CO2 emission factor.

No specific definition is provided for the city of Abu Dhabi in relation to the project.

The Project is eligible to be a VCS Project because:

PROJECT DESCRIPTION: VCS Version 3
Technology Transfer
There is no transfer of technology. The boiler and turbine installed under the project activity is of
indigenous technology and it is environmentally safe and project proponent is adhering to all the
safety norms applied to such project. The above mentioned technology is used for thermal energy
generation from renewable biomass. Uses of renewable fuels (carbon neutral fuel) will reduce the
GHG emission to the environment as compared to non-renewable fuels. Hence, the technology
employed by PP is environmentally safe. The technology is also well proven in India. The project
proponent is adhering on all safety norms used for boilers.
1.9 Project Location
The project site is located in P.O. Jagatjit Nagar (Hamira) Distt. Kapurthala (Punjab) - 144802. The
project site lies at the latitude 31027'26.47'' N and longitude 75 o 25' 57.09''E.

v3.3 8

PROJECT DESCRIPTION: VCS Version 3
1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Pre-project Scenario
The electric power and steam process demand of Jagatjit Industries Limited was met by coal fired
cogeneration plant which constituents three boilers of capacity 35, 25 and 25 TPH and with capacity
of 3 MW Turbine generator. Out of three Boilers, one boiler with 25 TPH capacities will be kept (as
standby) with project boilers and other two boilers had completed their lifetime and hence will be de-
installed. Coal was consumed in the pre-project activity scenario for thermal (steam) and electrical
energy generation and use in industrial process.
Project Scenario
The project activity entails installation of a cogeneration unit consisting of a 50 TPH boiler and a
6.94 MW steam turbine to generate both steam and power in an existing processing unit based on
rice husk. A 25 TPH old boiler will be kept as standby.
The estimated annual average emission reductions due to the project activity are 116,832 tCO2e
and the total GHG emission reductions for the fixed crediting period of 10 years is 1,168,320 tCO2e.
1.11 Compliance with Laws, Statutes and Other Regulatory Frameworks
The project is in compliance with relevant laws, statues and other regulatory frameworks. The
project does not violate any laws, statutes and or other regulatory frameworks in Punjab, India
1.12 Ownership and Other Programs
1.12.1 Project Ownership
The ownership of project activity to the project proponent can be verified through following
documents from the government-authorised bodies.
â¢ Commissioning Certificate
â¢ Power Purchase Agreement
â¢ Energy generation statement issued by state electricity board
â¢ Invoices
1.12.2 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
The net GHG emission reductions generated by the project activity will not be used for compliance
with an emissions trading program or to meet binding limits on GHG emissions.
1.12.3 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The project proponent hereby corroborates that the project activity has not created or sought or
received any other form of environmental credit.
1.12.4 Participation under Other GHG Programs
Project has been registered under CDM with the registered Project Id 9771.
1.12.5 Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
The project has not been rejected by any other GHG program
1.13 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Eligibility Criteria
Not Applicable
v3.3 9

The project area contains the project fields of rice merely, and the data of total area is confirmed by the Agriculture and Rural Affairs Bureau of Fuyuan City. The project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by replacing continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, this method can reduce the flooded time of rice in the whole growth cycle and the methane (CH4) emissions, and is more beneficial to production increase than the continuously flooded as well. Without the implementation of this project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the backward continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario.', 'project_state_province': 'Heilongjiang Province', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 47.91, 'project_longitude': 133.97}

ï»¿inputs.question: What is the project summary, province, country, latitude, and longitude of this project?
inputs.context:
VCS Project Description Template, v4.3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Malawi is one of the least developed countries (LDC) and among the poorest nations in the world1, with
a population whose lives and livelihoods are highly dependent on rain-fed agriculture and wood fuel
resources. Malawiâs forest areas have continuously decreased over recent decades2, and its growing
population coupled with the effects of a changing climate further exacerbates the countryâs historical
trend of deforestation and forest degradation. Forest loss in Malawi is a leading cause of soil degradation
and erosion, with cascading negative effects on water and soil nutrient availability that further challenges
smallholder agriculture in the country3, putting much of the populationâs overall resilience at risk.
In an effort to reverse this trend, Ripple Africa and GreenCollar are implementing a grouped afforestation
project in the Northern and Central regions of Malawi. The first activity instance of this grouped project
takes place in the District of Mzimba, with the planting of 1.8 million trees in 2022 and 2023. Subsequent
planting across the districts will be added to the grouped project as new activity instances.
Over 66% of Malawiâs forest area is located in the Northern and Central regions of the country. Malawi is
severely affected by deforestation with a high average annual rate of 1.5% between 2018-2022 and a
16% decrease in tree cover in 2001-20234. Deforestation is driven by the unsustainable and often illegal
collection of wood fuel and encroachment of farmland. The afforestation project will alleviate pressure
on existing forests in the Northern and Central regions of the country and integrate forest regeneration
into local community practices by planting trees on degraded land, fostering forest conservation, building
landholder capacity to manage and maintain planted forests and tree nurseries, and providing alternative
sources of income to the people participating in the program (hereafter, Registered Beneficiaries).
Furthermore, Ripple Africa will use a portion of the funding generated by the project through the sale of
carbon credits for additional activities that will benefit communities. This may include planting community
fruit trees in farms and schools and establishing Forest Conservation Committees to strengthen native
forest protection and regeneration in the region. Fruit tree planting and forest conservation activities will
enhance the positive climate, environmental and socioeconomic impact of the afforestation project but
will not generate additional VCUs for the project.
To implement the project, Ripple Africa has the approval of the Department of Forestry which will support
Ripple Africaâs engagement with local leaders and communities. To ensure the long-term success of the
project activities and the sustained growth of the planted trees, Ripple Africa will sign Tree Planting
Program Landholder Agreements with Registered Beneficiaries participating in the projectâs afforestation
activities. Ripple Africa has been implementing environmental, educational, and healthcare programs in
Malawi for the last 20 years, maintaining a strong local presence, and has prior experience planting trees
in the country.
1 https://www.un.org/development/desa/dpad/least-developed-country-category-malawi.html
2 Ministry of Natural Resources, Energy and Mining, Republic of Malawi (2019) Malawi REDD+ National Forest Reference
Level. 57 pp.
3 Ministry of Natural Resources, Energy and Mining, Republic of Malawi (2017) The National Forest Landscape
Restoration Strategy. 44 pp.
4 Global Forest Watch: https://www.globalforestwatch.org/
4

The project also involves planting community fruit trees and establishing Forest Conservation Committees.

confirmed by local government. Besides, Tianjin Gefei, as the PP, also takes efficient and effective
management of the project into consideration and designate Inner Mongolia Chengyao to address issues
that may arise locally.
So, Tianjin Gefei implement the project as Project Proponent during the whole project crediting period. The
Project Proponent should be responsible for the maintenance and overall management of the grassland
during the whole crediting period. In addition, the Project Proponent will also be responsible for
development of the carbon credits and the carbon revenue will be used for sustainable development and
management of the project activities.
Therefore, the Project Proponent of the project has the unconditional and undisputed ability to claim that
the project will generate the projectâs climate, community and biodiversity benefits.
2.5.10 Management of Double Counting Risk (G5.9)
This project will not seek to generate or have received any form of environmental or social credit.
2.5.11 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
The project is not involved in an emission trading program or any other mechanism that includes GHG
allowance trading. China Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) has been opened in July 2021. The major
industry that includes in ETS is electricity, as well as other seven industries (i.e. oil industry, chemical
industry, cement industry, iron and steel industry, non-ferrous metals industry, pulp and paper industry and
civil aviation industry). Grassland management project doesnât belong to any of the industry mentioned
above, the project is not included in Chinaâs emission trading system as well. Besides, the project proponent
had signed a declaration of âNo Double Counting Statementâ and declaration of ânot involved in other GHG
schemeâ to promise that no double count emissions reductions will appear in this project. Below are
excerpts from the declaration.
2.5.12 Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The project has not sought or received another form of GHG-related environmental credit.
2.5.13 Participation under Other GHG Programs
The project has not been registered, nor is seeking registration under any other GHG programs.

JOINT PROJECT DESCRIPTION & MONITORING REPORT: VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project and its Implementation Status
The project activity consists of 20 MW biomass-based power Plant at Nimdha (V), Dhenkanal
District, Orissa State. The project activity has been essentially conceived to generate GHG
emission free electricity by making use of available biomass at the project site to supply the
electricity to the grid. The project being a renewable energy project leads to sustainable
development through efficient utilization of available natural resources and generation of
additional employment for the local stakeholders.
The project activity is generation of electricity by utilizing surplus biomass residues like paddy
stalks, ground nut shell, stalks of red grams, mung, til, maize etc. agro industrial waste (rice
husk) and woody biomass (juliflora & casuarina twigs, etc) from agricultural/waste lands,
which are available in the project region and exporting the generated electricity to the grid
system owned by Orissa Power Transmission Corporation Limited (OPTCL), a state utility
which is part of grid.
As the project activities utilize naturally available Biomass project for power generation and do
not use any fossil fuels, the project contributes for reduction of greenhouse gases, which
would have, otherwise, been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants
and/or by addition of new generation sources.
Objective of the Project
The installations of the project activities have been carried out with a motive of generation of
electricity from environmentally benign source of energy. The project activity comprises of
biomass plant. The details of the investor along with the unique identification of the Plant have
been provided in Section A.4.2.
Nature of the Project
The basic technology involved in the project is is generating electricity using biomass
(agricultural residues) with a 90 TPH biomass fired boiler (BFBC) using a 23 MW turbine
whose capacity will be governed at 20MW. On an annual average basis, the project exports
around 124.57 GWh to the OPTCL grid, which is belongs to eastern grid, which is a part of the
NEWNE grid1. Considering auxiliary power consumption of 10 % the plant is expected to
operate at an annual average plant load factor of 80%.
1 NEWNE grid is now known as INDIAN grid

JOINT PROJECT DESCRIPTION & MONITORING REPORT: VCS Version 3
The PP of SGEL has entered into a long-term Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) with state
utility for a period of 20 years from the date of implementation of project.
Scenario existing prior to the implementation of project activity:
The scenario existing prior to the implementation of the project activity, is electricity delivered
to the grid by the project activity that would have otherwise been generated by the operation of
grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources, as reflected in the
combined margin (CM) calculations described in the âTool to calculate the emission factor for
an electricity systemâ.
Baseline Scenario:
As per the applicable methodology, a Greenfield power plant is defined as âa new renewable
energy power plant that is constructed and operated at a site where no renewable energy
power plant was operated prior to the implementation of the project activityâ.
As the project activity falls under the definition of a Greenfield power plant, the baseline
scenario as per paragraph 24 of Section 5.2.1 of applied methodology is the following:
If the project activity is the installation of a Greenfield power plant, the baseline scenario is
electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by
the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources,
as reflected in the combined margin (CM) calculations described in the âTool to calculate the
emission factor for an electricity systemâ.
Hence, pre-project scenario and baseline scenario are the same.
Contribution to GHG emissions reduction
The project activity harnesses wind energy to generate and supply electricity to the Indian
grid. The Project displaces fossil fuel-based electricity generation that would have otherwise
been provided by the operation and expansion of the fossil fuel-based power plants in regional
electricity grid, thereby leading to reduction in emission of greenhouse gases associated with
fossil fuel-based electricity generation.
As a result, GHG emission reductions by project is estimated to be approximately 104,744
tCO2e per year and total GHG emission reductions of 626,971 tCO2e for the crediting period,
thereon displacing 746,395 MWh/year amount of electricity from the gird.
The project is already registered with UNFCCC CDM (UN ref. no. 59052) on 18 Jul 2012 with
fixed crediting period 18 Jul 12 - 17 Jul 22.

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03
CDM â Executive Board 5
>>
Huitengliang, Xilinhot City
A.4.1.4. Detail of physical location, including information allowing the
unique identification of this project activity (maximum one page):
>>
The exact location of the project is defined using geographic coordinates obtained with a Global
Positioning System (GPS) receiver: E 116Â°13'30" Longitude, N 43Â°29'46" Latitude. These geographic
coordinates are for the centre of the wind farm.
Figure A.4.1.1 The location of Inner Mongolia in China

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03
CDM â Executive Board 6
Project Site
Figure A.4.1.1 The location of Xilinhot inInner Mongolia
A.4.2. Category(ies) of project activity:
>>
According to Annex A of the Kyoto Protocol, this project fits in Sectoral Category 1, Energy Industries
(renewable/non renewable).
A.4.3. Technology to be employed by the project activity:
>>
The purpose of the Project is to use well established wind power generation technology for electricity
generation and transmission to generate low emissions electricity for the Grid thereby displacing CO 2
emissions from electricity generation from the Grid. The baseline scenario is the same as the scenario
existing prior to the start of the implementation of the project activity: electricity delivered to the Grid by
the project would have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by
the addition of new generation sources. The Grid includes the Beijing, Tianjin, Hebei, Shanxi, Shandong
and Inner Mongolia Provincial Power Grids.
The proposed project involves the installation of 66 wind turbines each of which with a rated capacity of
750kW, providing a total capacity of 49.5MW. The expected annual electricity supply to the grid is
119,226MWh. The height of the rotor hub of all turbines is 60m. As the wind resource in the area is
plentiful, and the average wind speed is relatively high, averaging7.9m/s at a height of 55m and 8.1m/s at
a height of 65m, the wind resources are sufficient to run a wind farm at the location.
The construction includes a 220kV step-up substation. The wind power to be generated will be delivered
to the 220kV step-up substation by 35kV transmission lines. The electricity will be delivered from the
220kV step-up substation to the existing Huitengliang 220kV transformer substation. From the 220 kV
substation the electricity generated will be transmitted to the Inner Mongolia Power Grid.
Details on the monitoring equipments and their location are given in section B.7.2. of the PDD.

inputs.context:
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded conditions during rice
cultivation is conducted in the north of Qujing City, Yunnan Province, China, with a total acreage
of 12,106 ha of double-cropping rice. Without the project, there would be no ditches, pumps,
valves, and reservoirs to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously
flooded method would be continued. The original scenario in which rice was cultivated by the
continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under
flooded conditions can emit a large amount of methane because of anaerobic decomposition,
the intermittently flooded method is more conducive to saving water, increasing rice yield, and
reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded method.
The implementation activities of the project include cement ditch construction, reservoir
construction, pumps and valves installation, training, etc. According to the needs of rice growth,
farmers use pumps and valves to control irrigation and drainage, which not only saves water
resources but also reduces methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic
conditions. Through the pumps and valves, the necessary water can be supplied to the rice
paddies in time in the dry season, and the excess water can be drained from the rice paddies in
the rainy season. In this case, the methane emission can be declined by an average of 48%.
Hence, with the proposed project activity, the estimated GHG reduction from rice is 4.93
tCO e/ha. 2
The project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions by 418,012 tCO e in the first seven-year 2
period, with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 59,716 tCO e. The project aims to 2
reduce GHG and mitigate climate changes, increase rice productivity resulting in higher living
standards for local farmers and provide more job opportunities.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
This project is categorized as sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra as justified in Section 1.3,
although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is approved under sectoral scope 15 (Agriculture)
of CDM.
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 âAgriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU)â
with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land
Management (ALM).

So, this project can be\ncategorized as eligible ALM activity.'], ['The project area shall not be cleared of native\necosystems within 10 years before the project start\ndate.', 'The project area has not been cleared of native\necosystems since 2005.1'], ['Eligible ALM activities include:\nImproved Cropland Management (ICM): This category\nincludes practices that demonstrably reduce net GHG\nemissions of cropland systems by increasing soil\ncarbon stocks, reducing soil N O emissions, and/or\n2\nreducing CH emissions.\n4', 'This project practices intermittently flooded methods\non croplands, which is demonstrated that can reduce\nnet GHG emissions by reducing CH emissions. So, this\n4\nproject is an eligible ICM activity.']]

1.3 Project Eligibility
Although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is approved under sectoral scope 15 (Agriculture)
of CDM, this project is categorized as sectoral scope 14 (AFOLU) under Verra. This is by the
definitions of eligible AFOLU project categories set out in Appendix 1 of the VCS Standard, v4.2,
and can be demonstrated from the following three points.
1.
2.
3.
According to Section 2.1.1 of âVCS Standard version 4.2â, this project activity meets two of the
scopes of the VCS program:
1) The six Kyoto Protocol greenhouse gases.
4) Project activities supported by a methodology approved under a VCS approved GHG
program unless explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Accordingly, this project produces methane (CH ) emission reductions, which is one kind of the 4
six Kyoto Protocol GHGs. Besides, this project activity is supported by the CDM small-scale
methodology: Methane emission reduction by adjusted water management practice in rice
cultivation which is approved under a VCS approved GHG program â United Nations Clean
Development Mechanism and is not explicitly excluded under the terms of Verra approval.
Therefore, this project is eligible under the scope of the VCS program.
The project is an individual project, not a fragmented part of a larger project or activity.

The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded conditions during rice

model_answer: The methodology of this project is ACM0002 (version 10) - "Consolidated methodology for grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources." The project applies the "Tool for the Demonstration and Assessment of Additionality" (version 05.2) and the "Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system" (version 02). The project meets the applicability conditions of methodology ACM0002, which include being a grid-connected renewable wind power project, not involving switching from fossil fuels to renewable energy at the site, and having clear identification of the geographic and system boundaries of the SCPG to which the project will be connected.

VCS Project Description
â¢ The project activity contributes to economic sustainability around the plant site and encourages
economic power decentralization.
Environmental well-being:
â¢ The project utilizes hydropower to generate electricity, which otherwise would have been
generated through fuel- (most likely fossil-fuel-) based power plants. This way it is
contributing to a reduction in specific emissions (emissions of pollutant/unit of energy
generated), including GHG emissions.
â¢ As hydroelectric power projects produce no end-products in the form of solid waste (ash, etc.),
they donât have to cope with the problem of solid waste disposal encountered by most other
sources of power.
â¢ Being a renewable energy source, hydro energy is used to generate electricity that contributes
to resource conservation.
â¢ Thus, the project causes no negative impact on the surrounding environment; and in the end
contributes to environmental well being due to the run-off river type of project activity.
Technological well being:
â¢ The project supports high quality equipment transfer from other regions and even other
countries, and contributes to capacity building of the labor force through training and practical
work.
â¢ The project promotes local products developed in the region, when replacement of spare parts
is necessary, and supports renewable technology development especially for hydroelectric
power technology.
In view of the above explanation, the project participants consider the project activity as
profoundly contributing to sustainable development.

inputs.context:
Nascente Ceramic VCS Project Description
2 VCS Methodology:
2.1 Title and reference of the VCS methodology applied
to the project activity and explanation of methodology
choices:
! Category AMS-I.E: Switch from NonâRenewable Biomass for Thermal
Applications by the User â Version 01 from February 01 of 2008 onwards.
The amount of non-renewable biomass (B ) will be determined according to the y
option âbâ of the applied methodology once option âaâ is designed for really
small appliances like household stoves and does not fit for the kind of
projects in question.
The projectâs emissions from the combustion of native wood are accounted in
the same way as fossil fuel combustion, once it is not renewable and emits
CO . 2
2.2 Justification of the choice of the methodology and
why it is applicable to the project activity:
The methodology applied is Category AMS-I.E: Switch from NonâRenewable
Biomass for Thermal Applications by the User â Version 01 from February 01 of
2008 onwards which is applicable for project activities that avoid greenhouse
gas emissions by using renewable biomass in order to generate thermal energy.
This category comprises small thermal appliances that displace the use of
non-renewable biomass by introducing new renewable energy end-user
technologies. The end-user technology in the case of this project can be
established as the project proponent, who utilizes the thermal energy
generated by the new renewable energy technology.
There are no similar registered small-scale CDM project activities in the
region of Presidente Prudente once Social Carbon Company made a research and
did not find any registered smallâscale CDM Project activity in the region.
The sources of registered small-scale CDM project activity consulted were the
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) 14 and
Brazilianâs Technology and Science Ministry15. Therefore, the proposed project
activity is not saving the non-renewable biomass accounted by the other
registered project activities.
The utilization of firewood from area without any kind of management can not
be considered a renewable source of biomass, since it involves a decrease of
carbon pools and increases the carbon emissions to the atmosphere, turning
green house effect even worse. Moreover, the native wood provided from areas
without a reforestation management plan does not fit any of the options of
UNFCCC definition of renewable biomass in Annex 18, EB 23.
Furthermore, firewood has been used for many decades as fuel in Brazil16.
Although, it is impossible to define a start date on which this kind of non-
renewable biomass began to be applied, there are many documents to prove that
wood has been used for thermal energy generation before 1989 as requested in
the applied methodology. Firewood used to be the most employed source of
primary energy until de decade of 1970, when the petroleum started to supply

http://cdm.unfccc.int/Projects/registered.html>. visited on May 11th, 2009.

of all CDM activities within Brazilian boundaries. CDM activities submitted to the
Brazilian Inter-Ministerial Commission of CDM Activities are available at:
http://www.mct.gov.br/index.php/content/view/47952.html. Visited on May 11th, 2009.

para estimaÃ§Ã£o de consumo, tese de doutorado, Universidade de SÃ£o Paulo, SÃ£o paulo,

14052008-113901/ >. Visited on December 12th, 2008
12

Nascente Ceramic VCS Project Description
the majority of Brazilianâs energy needs17. Moreover the Brazilianâs Energy
and Mine Ministry has been monitoring every energetic sectors of Brazil since
1970, and firewood appears over the years monitored as a significant source
of thermal energy for ceramic sector18. Especially in the ceramic sector, the
use of firewood is visible non-renewable and unsustainable, involving
negative environmental impacts associated19.
This way, it can be concluded that non-renewable biomass has been used since
31 December 1989.
The biomasses utilized in the project, sawdust and sugar cane bagasse, are
common residue in the region generated.
Sawdust, wood chips, peanut shells and sugar cane bagasse are all industries
residues coming from large scale reforestation or agroindustrial projects, so
it is considered renewable according to option V of methodology definition of
renewable biomass: âThe biomass is the non-fossil fraction of an industrial
or municipal wasteâ.
The elephant grass is considered renewable according to option III, as soon
as it fits all the assumptions below:
âThe biomass is non-woody biomass and originates from croplands and/or
grasslands where:
(a) The land area remains cropland and/or grasslands or is reverted to
forest; and
(b) Sustainable management practices are undertaken on these land areas to
ensure in particular that the level of carbon stocks on these land areas does
not systematically decrease over time (carbon stocks may temporarily decrease
due to harvesting); and
(c) Any national or regional forestry, agriculture and nature conservation
regulations are complied with.â
Moreover, the project activity will annually generate less than 45 MWThermal.
2.3 Identifying GHG sources, sinks and reservoirs for
the baseline scenario and for the project:
According to the applied methodology, the project boundaries for the project
are the physical, geographical areas of the use of biomass or the renewable
energy, thus, the ceramic limits.
In the baseline scenario, there is use of non-renewable biomass to burn
ceramic devices in the ceramicâs kilns. This practice is responsible to
discharge in the atmosphere the carbon that was stored inside of the wood
(well-known by a carbon sink).

model_answer: The methodology applied in this project is Category AMS-I.E: Switch from Non-Renewable Biomass for Thermal Applications by the User â Version 01 from February 01 of 2008 onwards. This methodology is applicable for project activities that avoid greenhouse gas emissions by using renewable biomass to generate thermal energy. The project utilizes sawdust, wood chips, peanut shells, sugar cane bagasse, and elephant grass as renewable biomass. The baseline scenario for the project involves the use of non-renewable biomass (wood) to burn ceramic devices in ceramic kilns, which results in the release of carbon into the atmosphere.

 16
 
 
Step 4. Common practice analysis 
 
Sub-step 4a. Analyze other activities similar to the proposed project activity: 
 
The biomass produced by the forestry industry is on e of the non-conventional renewable energy sources 
used in Chile (a share of 14 % of the national ener gy pool), and is mainly represented by wood, whose 
consumption is up to 12 millions of m3, which is most provided by natural forests.  However, with an 
increasing trend, the waste from the lumber indus try based on plantations is being progressively 
incorporated like a source to supply energy needs of this same industry2. 
 Nevertheless, despite the increasing utilization in the lumber industry, making use of waste of the forestry activities as a fuel to generate heat or electri city is not a common practice amongst the fishery 
manufacturing and processing.  This fact is supported because the most of fishery industries operating in 
Chile are using fossil fuel technologies in order to cover their needs of steam, heat and electricity.  The following table shows some examples of the fishery or food companies and some features of their boilers 
to meet energy requirements.  These facilities are mainly located within Region X and IX:

 Besides these companies, there are others those have developed energy projects based on biomass during last years.  These projects, however, have incorpor ated the CDM component to their development; these 
initiatives are:  (i) Russfin Biomass CHP Plant Project , (ii) Trupan Biomass Power Plant in Chile, (iii) 
Nueva Aldea Biomass Power Plant Phase 1 and Phase II.  Nevertheless, these are slightly different from 
Panitao Biomass Thermal Energy Project, because in this  case the biomass will be used only to generate 
steam (heat), meanwhile the CDM projects are cogenera ting heat and electricity based in by-products of 
the lumber industry.

According to VCS standard, the project start date is the date on which activities that lead to the
generation of GHG emission reductions or removals are implemented, for this project, the project start
date is 23-May-2015 when the planting started.
2.1.15 Benefits Assessment and Crediting Period (G1.9)
Planting started: 23-May-2015, the date on which the native community started its activities and led to
greenhouse gas removal.
The project crediting period is from 01-January-2016 to 31-December-2035, and the project lifetime is 30
years from 23-May-2015 to 22-May-2045.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
2 APPLICATION OF METHODOLOGY
2.1 Title and Reference of Methodology
The following approved baseline and monitoring methodology is applicable to the project activity:
- For the power generation using renewable sources that supply electricity to and/or displace
electricity from an electricity distribution system, the baseline methodology applied to the
project is ACM0002 Large-scale Consolidated Methodology / âGrid-connected electricity
generation from renewable sourcesâ- version 18.1
(http://cdm.unfccc.int/filestorage/2/L/9/2L9KQXT6HGREJWO84VD0IPYB7U5SMA/Grid-
connected%20electricity%20generation%20from%20renewable%20sources.pdf?t=OVJ8cGF
wYngwfDC5ov6CuIk6U7crJTMPpVu5).
The methodology also considers the latest versions of the following approved methodological
tools:
- Tool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system â version 6.0
(https://cdm.unfccc.int/methodologies/PAmethodologies/tools/am-tool-07-v6.pdf);
- Tool for the demonstration and assessment of additionality â version 07.0.0
(http://cdm.unfccc.int/methodologies/PAmethodologies/tools/am-tool-01-v7.0.0.pdf);
- Methodological tool Investment analysis â version 8
(https://cdm.unfccc.int/methodologies/PAmethodologies/tools/am-tool-27-
v8.pdf/history_view);
- Methodological tool Common practice â version 3.1
(http://cdm.unfccc.int/methodologies/PAmethodologies/tools/am-tool-24-v1.pdf);
- Tool to determine the remaining lifetime of equipment â version 1
(http://cdm.unfccc.int/methodologies/PAmethodologies/tools/am-tool-10-v1.pdf).
- Methodological tool to calculate project or leakage CO2 emissions from fossil fuel
combustionâ â version 03.0.
http://cdm.unfccc.int/methodologies/PAmethodologies/tools/am-tool-03-v3.pdf
- Methodological tool Baseline, project and/or leakage emissions from electricity consumption
and monitoring of electricity generationâ â version 03.0
http://cdm.unfccc.int/methodologies/PAmethodologies/tools/am-tool-05-v3.0.pdf
2.2 Applicability of Methodology
The consolidated methodology ACM0002 version 18.1 is applicable to grid-connected renewable
power generation projects that:
a. Install a Greenfield power plant;
b. Involve a capacity addition to existing plants;
c. Involve a retrofit of (an) existing plant(s)/unit(s); or
d. Involve a rehabilitation of (an) existing plant(s)/unit(s);
e. Involve a replacement of (an) existing plant(s)/unit(s).
As the project corresponds to the installation of a new power plant at a site where a renewable
power plant has not been operated (Greenfield power plant), the project fulfils condition a);
therefore, consolidated methodology ACM0002 is the most appropriate methodology for the
project. In addition, the methodology is applicable under the following conditions:

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
Table: Applicability conditions
2.3 Project Boundary
According to consolidated methodology, ACM0002 version 18.1, project boundary considers the
spatial extent including the project power plants and all power plants connected physically to the
electricity system. Therefore, for the project, the boundary encompasses the water diversion
system, the new turbine generator systems, and equipment required to export the electricity to the
grid (transformers, substations, etc). The figure below shows a representation of the project
boundary.

identification of this project activity (maximum one page):

The Hornitos Hydroelectric Project is located near Los Andes city. This is approximately 100 km
northeast from Santiago (capital of the country). The hydro power plant will be located in a small valley
surrounded by mountains (Aconcagua Valley). The Hornitos Hydroelectric Project power plant is in
cascade with three other existing downstream hydropower plants (Aconcagua of 72 MW, Los Quilos of
39 MW and Chacabuquito 26 MW).
The international road Ch-60 from Los Andes to Mendoza is the main access road to the project.
Secondary and rural roads connect settlements and camps along that highway. There is little population in
the project area, which is mostly a mountain area.

ï»¿inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.context:
Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.2
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Aurum Sustainable Forest Inc (Aurum) is developing a forest carbon credit project to generate
greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions and removals by extending the rotation age of their
operational forests. In addition to increasing the age of their forestlands, the Goldbeck Forest Carbon
Project (Goldbeck) will be reverting stand compositions back to natural longleaf pine forests where
appropriate. The carbon credit project will be implemented following the Verified Carbon Standard
(VCS) VM0003 â Methodology for Improved Forest Management Through Extension of Rotation Age
(IFM ERA).
Project instances will be implemented in the states of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi,
North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas and Virginia; of the United States. The current project instance is
approximately 4,140 ha and is composed of non-contiguous parcels. The project has been designed as
a grouped project to allow for additional project activity instances to be added in the future. Additional
project activity instances implemented will be within a similar geographic area, allowing for the use of
the initial project baseline scenario for additionality purposes.
All activity instances included in the project are currently managed for timber harvest, and all forests
within the project activity instances are Forest Stewardship CouncilÂ® (FSCÂ®) certified, meeting the
VM0003 methodology requirement. Implementation of the project activity will result in the removal of
an estimated annual average of 309,030 tCO2e and total of 9,270,890 tCO2e over the 30-year project
period.
The project is currently under development. Monitoring results may impact the greenhouse gas
emissions reductions results that are currently presented in this version.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope 14
Improved Forest Management (IFM)
Extended Rotation Age (IFM ERA)
The Goldbeck project is a grouped project, allowing for the addition of project activity instances
following project validation.
Goldbeck Forest Carbon Project â V1.1 1

Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.2
1.3 Project Eligibility
The Goldbeck project satisfies all Improved Forest Management (IFM) project activities involving an
Extension of Rotation Age (ERA):
1. Forest management in both the baseline and project scenarios involve timber harvest.
2. All forest areas included in the project area are subject to forest management and timber
harvest activities.
3. All forest areas included in the project are forest management certified by the Forest
Stewardship Council by the start of the project crediting period (F&W Forestry Services Inc.
Group Certificate â Certificate Code: NC-FM/COC-000216).
4. The minimum project period is 30-years.
5. The project area does not include managed peatland forests and will not alter the proportion of
wetlands because of project activities.
6. Management practices have been projected for both with and without project scenario.
7. Fire may be used as part of forest management but fire control measures are taken to ensure
fire does not spread outside the project area.
8. There will be no leakage resulting from activity shifting to other lands owned or managed by the
project proponent outside the bounds of the project area.
1.4 Project Design
The Goldbeck project is a grouped project to be composed of non-contiguous parcels in Alabama,
Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas and Virginia. The
baseline scenario was established using the existing forest management plan and management regime
for the project area. The baseline scenario and additionality assessments have been completed within
a defined geographic area. The project is composed of multiple project activity instances that will be
implemented under the VM0003 methodology. The baseline scenario has been determined for one
geographic area, and the same baseline scenario and geographic area will be used for additional
project activity instances which may occur following project validation.
Eligibility Criteria
Inclusion of additional activity instances will satisfy the following eligibility criteria:
1. Additional instances must satisfy the applicability conditions defined in the most recent
version of the VM0003 VCS Methodology for Improved Forest Management Through
Extension of Rotation Age (IFM ERA).
2. The project activity instance must use technologies or measures used in this document and
must satisfy all conditions of the selected methodology.
3. Technologies or measures must be applied in a similar fashion as outlined in the project
description document.
Goldbeck Forest Carbon Project â V1.1 2
model_answer: The project sector is Forestry and Land Use.

3.2 Applicability of Methodology
.
In accordance with the selected methodology AR-ACM0003 version 1.0.0, it is applicable if the
project activity meets the following conditions:
1. It does not fall in wetland category:
Project areas are not covered or saturated by water for all or part of the year (e.g.,
peatland)

of area in each of the following types of land when these lands are included within the project
boundary:
(i) Land containing organic soils;
(ii) Land which, in the baseline, is subjected to land-use and management practices
and receives inputs listed in appendices 1 and 2 to this methodology:
Project areas do not contain organic soils and are not subjected to land-use practices and
do not receive inputs as those described below:
- Short-term or set aside croplands with full tillage and high inputs with manure or
- Short-term or set aside croplands with reduced tillage and medium inputs or
- Short-term or set aside croplands with reduced tillage and high inputs with or without
manure or
- Short term or set aside croplands without tillage
Only subsistence agriculture (rainy agriculture) is practiced in some project areas
- Grassland with improved or non-degraded management:
Only transhumance grazing activities are present in the project area

East. Pingjiang County is located in the northeastern part of Hunan Province, upstream of Miluo
River. It borders Xiushui County and Tonggu County of Jiangxi Province to the east, Miluo City to
the west, Liuyang City and Changsha County to the south, and Tongcheng County and Yueyang
County of Hubei Province to the north. It is 98.5 kilometers long from east to west, 76.1 kilometers
wide from north to south, with a total area of 4,125 square kilometers, and the resident
population of Pingjiang County is 951,112,

specified by the VCS standard as Pingjiang County, and the project area is defined as the rice

1.13 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Intermittent flooded water regime requires that irrigation and drainage can be controlled
according to the growth needs of rice during its cultivation. However, prior to the project initiation,
economic conditions in the project area are not very good and farmersâ income was low, which
resulted in that the farmers in the project area had no extra money to build the cement ditches,
ponds and other infrastructure for intermittent irrigation. In addition, farmers in the project area
have low education level, so they lack intermittent irrigation technology. So, the project has not
been implemented to generate GHG emissions for the purpose of their subsequent reduction,
removal or destruction. Since the conditions existing prior to the project initiation is the same as
baseline scenario, please refer to Section 3.4 (Baseline Scenario) to see the detail information.
Besides, this project does not affect the environmental conditions, including climate, hydrology,
topography, soils, relevant historical conditions, type of vegetation, ecosystems, etc., so, the
present and prior environmental conditions of this project are the same, which are listed as
follows.
11

Eligibility Criteria

Leakage Management

Commercially Sensitive Information
There is no information that needs to be excluded from the public version of the VCS PD which

Further Information
The project is a renewable energy project for power generation that enables the substitution for
fossil fuel based electricity. The contribution of the project activity towards sustainable development
in Turkey is regarded as follows:
Kale HEPP contributes to the regionâs sustainable development in particular and Turkeyâs
sustainable development in the following manner: (a) social well-being, (b) economical well-being,
(c) environmental well-being and (d) technological well-being.
Specifically, the Project contributes in the social and economic development in the project area
significantly as the following:
1. Employment of the local people in the construction process has been provided.
2. Scholarships have been given to some local students.
3. Construction works of the local people have been helped
In addition, the project activity contributes in the environmental and technological development in
the project area significantly as the following:
1. The scheme will not alter any environmental or biological attributes of the area.
2. The project activity will not result in degradation of any natural resources, health standards,
etc. in the project area.
3. As the project is hydro based it will generate clean energy, real, measurable and long-term
emissions reductions of green house gases.
4. Project activity would utilize potential water resources available in the area for exploiting all
possible resources for local development thus illustrating the effective utilization of renewable
energy sources available in the area.
5. The project will utilise environmentally safe and sound technology in the hydroelectric power
sector.
Furthermore, it is important to note that within the geographical boundaries of the project acitivity,
there are no national parks, cultural sites, hunting areas or wild animal reproduction areas.13

inputs.context:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1. Timber harvesting and tree removals: This may include thinning, group or individual tree
selective harvest, salvage, and/or other forest management strategies. These activities
will typically be implemented to restore or enhance natural forest composition and
structure, create or accelerate future forest or ecosystem features and development,
and/or to mitigate or manage forest health, fire, or forest disturbance risks or events,
and/or for other ecosystem-based objectives.
2. Access development: The project will manage road development and access at a
property level with an objective of limiting road development while allowing access for
project activities including road maintenance, forest management, forest health and fire
management, recreational access and/or other access requirements.
3. Tree planting or other silvicultural activities to improve and/or accelerate ecological
function and forest ecological development towards desired future conditions.
Other project activities that will not materially affect carbon stocks include:
1. Monitoring â monitoring is primarily undertaken using a combination of site supervision,
remote sensing, and the establishment and measurement of non-destructive permanent
sample plots.
2. Recreational Access Development â DNRP manages the installation and maintenance of
trails for non-motorized recreational access. This activity may involve limited single tree
removals, hazard tree or other safety removals, and/or other limited management
activities related to public hiking and access that are anticipated to have a de minimis
impact on carbon stocks across the project.
Project activities on King County properties are planned and managed by DNRP Parks Division
staff, with input and technical support from other divisions. Participating 3rd Party Landowners will
plan project activities in conjunction with DNRP forestry staff in the Water and Land Resources
Division and 3rd party consultants under the terms of the Participation Agreement each 3rd Party
Landowner has entered into. As sole Project Proponent, DNRP is the sole contact for the project
and will maintain and oversee all project monitoring and reporting responsibilities and activities for
all project instances.
The project is not located within a jurisdiction covered by a jurisdictional REDD+ program.
1.9 Project Location
The project geographic area encompasses King County, an area of 2,302 sq. mi (5,980 km2)
located in the State of Washington in the northwest coast of the United States; on and about 47Â°
28' 12.00" N, -121Â° 50' 24.00" W (Figure 1). Approximately 2,111 mi2 (5,484 km2) or 91.7% of King
County is land and 191 mi2 (490 km2) is open water. King County extends from Puget Sound on the
west to the crest of the Cascade Mountains in the east. King County is bounded by Kitsap County
on the west, Kittitas and Chelan Counties on the east, Snohomish County to the north and Pierce
County to the south. King County encompasses the major cities of Seattle, Tacoma, and Bellevue
along with many smaller towns and municipalities. Washington state is located in the Pacific
Northwest (PNW), a geographic region in western North America bounded by the Pacific Ocean to
the west and by the Cascade Mountain Range on the east.
v3.3 8

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
King County supports a population of approximately 2.23 million residents (2018) and
encompasses the major cities of Seattle (2018 population: 730,400), Bellevue (141,400), Kent
(127,500) and Renton (101,000) along with many smaller cities and unincorporated areas. King
County is the most populous county in Washington, and has experienced a significant increase in
growth in recent decades; the county added approximately 300,000 residents since 2010.
Although population growth in King County has apparently slowed somewhat recently, net
population increase between 2017 and 2018 was still 80 people per day.

1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
Generally, most rural forested private lands in King County are either managed for timber
production or for rural residential acreages. Properties managed for timber can have a variety of
management activities and intensities, but predominantly forests are clearcut at age ~40 years old
and then replanted to conifer. Outside of protected private land, most forests have been heavily cut
and regenerated one or more times since the late 1800s. Most managed properties undergo
additional silvicultural activities including a pre-commercial thin, hardwood management, and fill
planting understocked areas, etc. The general objective is fast timber growth to reduce rotation
ages and maximize financial returns. The forest industry is large and well established throughout
most of Washington State and King County.

inputs.context:
In response to these adverse threats to the eco-region the Oromia Regional Government has attempted to
take concrete actions in recent years through policy and institutional development reforms. Establishment of
Oromia Forest and Wildlife Enterprise (OFWE) is one of these concrete actions taken. However, capacity
and resources are still major limiting factors for OFWE to achieve significant outcome in improved
management of the forests and associated natural resources in the eco-region. This BMERP is designed to
create a sustainable financing mechanism to help government and local communities build capacity and fill
critical resource gaps to bring meaningful changes in the management of natural resources and forests in
the eco-region.
The BMERP will build itself on works under implementation in the eco-region. From 2007 - 2012, Farm
Africa/ SOS Sahel Ethiopia in partnership with the Oromia Forest and Wildlife Enterprise implemented the
Bale Eco-Region Sustainable Management Programme (BERSMP), supported by the Netherlands,
Norwegian and Irish Embassies in Ethiopia. The programme aimed to contribute to the conservation and
sustainable development of the unique biodiversity and ecological functions of the greater Bale Mountains
Eco-region, whilst establishing and enhancing sustainable local livelihoods. The idea was to involve local
communities into a central role in the sustainable management of the area, and as the natural resource
management leaders, supported by government services, across the whole Bale Massif. The Bale
Mountains Eco-Region REDD+ initiative started as part of the bigger programme to address the financial
sustainability of the programme.
Figure 13. Agricultural frontiers expansion into moist forest of Harenna, Bale Eco-Region
There has been little active or effective management of natural resources in the area. Unsustainable
exploitation and degradation throughout the eco-region is increasingly threatening the natural resources
thereby the livelihoods of the local people that directly dependent on them as well as the very survival of a
unique biodiversity resources whose economic potential as a basis for tourism in particular remains
unfulfilled. Under business as usual, the3 eco-region will be on the verge of significant degradation
threatening not only the unique biodiversity of the area but livelihoods of millions of community that directly
and indirectly depend on goods and services from the eco-region. Action should be taken urgently to save
this globally important ecosystem.
1.4 Project Proponent G1.1
The BMERP proponent is the Oromia Forest and Wildlife Enterprise (OFWE), an autonomous fully
government-owned enterprise, established with regulation number 122/2009 issued in July 2009 by the
Oromia State Council under the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia. The Oromia Forest and Wildlife
Enterprise owns concession for all of the forests and regionally administered wildlife related conservation
area in Oromia State. The concession area of OFWE covers a total of 367,700 Km2.
OFWEâs mission is to undertake conservation, sustainable development and utilization of the forest and
wildlife resources in its concessions through community participation; ensure supply of forest products
markets and services to domestic and international markets by enhancing forest industry; and subsequently
contribute to the regional and national socio-economic development endeavours.
33

The project proponent, OFWE, is currently responsible for the management of all forests in Oromia regional
state of Ethiopia. The forests were given to OFWE by concession to administer and manage it. OFWE has 9
branch enterprises, where Bale Mountains REDD+ mountains REDD+ project fall in two of the forest
enterprises: Arsi and Bale branches. The two branch enterprises with the OFWE headquarter support will be
responsible for the implementation of the BMERP.
In line with this they will perform the following:
ï· developing work plans and budgets
ï· implementation of activities such as law enforcement, community nursery establishment and
management
ï· support community forest management groups in the implementation of participatory forest
management
ï· closely work with legal bodies to enforce law
ï· ensure participation of other government agencies such as the office of agriculture, energy, etc in
the project implementation
ï· coordination of involvement of non-governmental organizations
OFWE staff profile:
OFWE has a total of3543 staffs working in the different branch offices and districts, out of which 117 staffs
are directly related to the Bale Eco-Region. These are working in two of the branch offices in Bale and West
Arsi within which the Bale eco-region forests fall.
Besides their professional background and skill in forest and biodiversity management the Bale REDD+
project has also provided series of training to build the capacity of the OFWE in REDD+ project management
and implementation. The Bale and Arsi branch office OPFWE staff were the one that conducted the forest
inventory work for the development of this PDD as well.
The Bale REDD+ piloting project (2012-2015) has also developed and is implementing Government and
Community staff capacity building plan (Government and community capacity building plan supplementary
material 25).
Farm Africa and SOS Sahel-Ethiopia, who supported OFWE in the development of the Bale REDD+ pilot
project and this PDD are also supporting the proponent in implementing the project activities until 2015, and
beyond through their current projects such as Bale REDD+ pilot project and SHARE projects (additional
documents enclosed as references). This will also strengthen the proponent in developing additional
capacity.

Joint forest management (JFM) cooperatives are community based organizations (CBO) established and
certified by the Oromia regional state Cooperative promotion office. The JFM CBOs, after getting certificate
of formal institution, sign a forest management agreement with the Oromia Forest & Wildlife Enterprise to
jointly manage the forest in their territory/kebele. The activities they do are sustainable forest management:
forest protection, development, utilization, and M&E.

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03  
 
CDM â Executive Board     Page 3  
 
 
Environment well being: 
â¢ Reduction in the consumption of fossil fuels:  The installation of power plant generating 
electricity through utilization of renewable res ource such as wind power, would lead to reduction 
in usage of fossil fuels such as coal. 
â¢ Reduction in emission of GHG: The reduction in usage of fossil fuels for electricity generation 
will result in reduction of the release of associated GHG  emissions (CO 2 and CH 4 emissions).  
â¢ Improvement of Air Quality: The use of renewable energy for power generation will avoid the 
emission of air pollutants such as Suspended Particulate Matter (SPM), Sulphur Dioxide (SO 2) 
and Nitrogen Oxides (NO x) thereby improvising the surrounding air quality  
â¢ Conservation of Natural Resources: Installation of wind power plant will result in conserving 
fast depleting natural resources such as coal, oil etc.  
 
Economic well being: 
â¢ Rural Development:  The installation of wind power project will result in rural and 
infrastructural development in the surrounding rural areas 
â¢ Economic Development:  The generation of wind power will result in improvising the reliability 
of the Southern Grid and thereby enha nce economic development in the region. 
 
Social well being: 
â¢ Generating Local Employment: The installation of wind power project in rural areas will result 
in generating local employment opportunities and capacity building of the local employees. 
â¢ Encouragement to entrepreneurs:  The project will provide encouragement to other 
entrepreneurs to invest into renewable energy sources. 
 
Technological well being: 
â¢ The project activity involves the successful installa tion and operation of state-of-art wind turbine 
generators (WTGs) of Vestas make. The implem entation of these new technologies will help in 
increasing reliability on efficient technology and large capacity wind mills. 
 
Community Development:  
Powerica would use, at a minimum, 2% of the revenues accrued from the sale of Certified Emission 
Reductions (CERs) on an annual basis for commun ity related activities. These may include providing 
assistance for development of public amen ities in the surrounding areas such as water 
distribution/sanitation facilities/building of School a nd Hospital/ free distribution of educational books 
and school uniforms/annual eye camps/health check up centres for villagers etc.  If the activity undertaken involves capital expenditure  exceeding the minimum requirement of 2%, the 
additional expenditure made would be setoff against the requirements for the subsequent years. Such 
expenditure would be made within one year after th e realization of revenues from the sale of the CERs. 
Monitoring plan proposed for the expenditure is included in Annex 4 of the PDD.

inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Hulin within Jixi City, Heilongjiang Province of China, with a total
acreage of 20,206 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this project,
which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the continuously flooded
method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded
method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition
can emit a large amount of methane (CH ) because of anaerobic decomposition, the 4
intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase
and methane emission reduction than the continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results
in not only large amount of methane (CH ) emissions but also low rice productivity by 4
replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens
the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH emission 4
can be declined by an average of 48%1 . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an
estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 2.92 tCO e/ha for single-cropping rice is 2
expected.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to
413,462 tCO e in the first 7 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 2
59,066tCO e. 2
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 âAgriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
(AFOLU)â with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under
Agricultural Land Management (ALM). Although the AMS-III.AU methodology applied is
1 Dr. Reiner Wassmann (2016). Coordinator, Climate Change Research. International Rice Research

Contribution of the project activity to sustainable development
The project primarily assists the state of Karnataka and India as a whole in stimulating and accelerating the
commercialization of grid connected renewable energy technologies. In addition to this, wind power
projects like this demonstrates the viability of grid connected wind farms, which improve energy security,
air quality and local livelihoods, as well as assisting the development of a domestic sustainable renewable
energy industry. The specific goals of the project are:
(cid:127) Sustainable development through generation of eco-friendly power;
(cid:127) Increasing the share of renewable energy power generation in the regional and national grid;
(cid:127) To bridge Indiaâs energy deficit in the business as usual scenario;
(cid:127) Providing national energy security, especially when global fossil fuel reserves threaten the long term
sustainability of the Indian economy;
(cid:127) Strengthening Indiaâs rural electrification coverage;
Â· Essentially reducing GHG emissions compared to a business-as-usual scenario;
(cid:127) Reducing other pollutants (SO , NO , PM, etc.) resulting from power generation industry; x x
(cid:127) Contribute towards reducing power shortage especially in the state of Karnataka, India;
(cid:127) Demonstrate and help in stimulating the growth of the wind power industry in India;
(cid:127) Enhancing local employment in the vicinity of the project, which is a rural area;
(cid:127) Capacity building and empowerment of vulnerable sections of the rural communities dwelling in the
project area;
(cid:127) Power generation from Renewable Energy sources paves way for energy security of future
generations;
(cid:127) Conserving natural resources including land, forests, minerals, water and ecosystems;
The National strategy for sustainable development also aims at providing access to clean energy with the
objective that increased availability of power in the rural areas will lead to industrial activity aimed at
generating employment and reduce poverty. For these reasons, the wind power project of Savita group is
fully in line with the overall goals for sustainable development of the Government of India (GOI) and the
requirement of Karnataka state.
Ministry of Environment and Forests, Govt. of India has stipulated the social well being, economic well
being, environmental well being and technological well being as the four indicators for sustainable
development in the host country approval eligibility criteria for Clean Development Mechanism (CDM)
projects1, which is in accordance of VCS guidelines.

The proposed project is the installation of a new grid-connected renewable power plant,
and the baseline scenario is the following:
Electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been
generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new
generation sources, as reflected in the combined margin (CM) calculations described in
the âTool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity systemâ.
A project electricity system is defined by the spatial extent of the power plants that can be
dispatched without significant transmission constraints. The proposed project delivers its
electricity generated to Northeast China Power Grid. The spatial extent of the project boundary
includes the proposed project and all power plants connected physically to the Northeast China
Power Grid that the CDM project power plant is connected to. The grid boundaries definition was
1 used with DNA guidance . For the proposed project, the Northeast China Power Grid was as the

model_answer:
Methodology of this project: 

The methodology applied to the project activity is the approved consolidated baseline and monitoring methodology ACM0002 "Consolidated baseline methodology for grid-connected electricity generation from renewable sources" (ACM 0002 Version 11). This methodology utilizes tools for calculating the emission factor for an electricity system and for the demonstration and assessment of additionality. The project involves the installation of a new grid-connected zero-emission renewable power generation activity from wind source. The sources and gases included in the project boundary are CO2 emissions from electricity generation in fossil fuel-fired power plants that are displaced due to the project. CH4 and N2O are minor emission sources that are not included in the project boundary. The project activity involves the delivery of electricity generated to the Northeast China Power Grid. The monitoring plan includes the measurement of net electricity generation supplied by the project plant to the grid, with data recorded monthly and archived electronically. QA/QC procedures are implemented to ensure the accuracy of metering equipment and the adherence to monitoring and management regulations for CDM projects. Double checks are done using sales receipts to verify electricity exported to the grid.

reductions or removal enhancements
The risks that may affect the projectâs GHG emission reductions are given below:
A. Wind electricity generation is risky and unpredictable due to the variability involved in
wind resources as well as its forecasting. This variability is due to the variability in the
wind speed and wind pattern, which in turn depends on weather cycle, climatic
conditions, etc.
B. The project is dependent on the utility provider for grid availability. If there is a grid
failure, the project will be unable to supply the generated electricity to the grid.

CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
2 GENERAL
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
Tibet Ngari Improved Grassland Management Project (hereafter as âthe projectâ) is located in
Ngari Region, Tibet Autonomous Region, China. Ngari is located in the southwest border of
China, the west of Tibet Autonomous Region and the north of Qinghai Tibet Plateau (Qiangtang
plateau). The objective of the project is to restore the "black soil beach14" and degraded
grassland ecosystem through reseeding native grasses and grazing management, such as rest
grazing and grazing prohibition, increase carbon sequestration, and promote local development.
The project proponent is National Forestry and Grassland Administration Northwest Investigation
and Planning Institute.
The project area is located in Ngari, covering Gar County, Burang County, Zanda County, Rutog
County, GÃª'gyai County, GÃªrzÃª County and CoqÃªn County. According to the Participatory Rural
Appraisal (PRA) report. Before the implementation of the project, there were severely degradation
and desertification of the grasslands in this area due to the impact of climate change and human
activities, some grassland even degenerated into "black soil beach", the excellent forages in the
plant community almost disappeared, and the natural reproduction and renewal ability was very
low. According to the Parameters for Degradation, Desertification and Salinization of Rangeland
(GB19377-2003) in China15, moderately degraded grassland areas refer to the total grass yield
decreased by 21%-50% compared with that before degradation and the total grass yield
decreased by more than 50% compared with that before degradation is regarded as severely
degraded grasslands.
Totally, 373,467.02 ha of degraded grassland in Ngari have been managed sustainably including
rest grazing and grazing prohibition by fence building and seeding of local high-quality forage.
There are three main restoration measures as followed in the project:
(1) Rest grazing was implemented in moderately degraded grassland areas where grass yield
was 130-190kg/Mu 16 which decreased by 21-50% compared with the non-degraded
grassland. It is required that grazing shall not be allowed within 120 days when the grass
turns green every year (from 01-May to 31-August) through the construction of fence and
sustainable management. Through the implementation of rest grazing, 322,770.02 ha of
degraded grassland were managed sustainably.
(2) Grazing prohibition was implemented in seriously degraded grasslands where grass yield
less than 130 Kg/Mu which decreased by more than 50% compared with the non-degraded
grassland. Fence building shall be carried out in the grazing prohibition area. When the
construction is completed, grazing prohibition shall be implemented for 5 years. After that,
14 "Black soil beach" is an extreme type of grassland degradation caused by overgrazing, human factors, rat and
insect damage, climate warming and other factors.
15GB19377-2003 is a national standard document of the people's Republic of China which issued by The Ministry of
Agriculture and Rural Affairs to assess the level of degradation, desertification and salinization of natural grassland.
The original website of the standard is
http://c.gb688.cn/bzgk/gb/showGb?type=online&hcno=5F1960D0692A36C09136E04E6DE60B4E
16 1ha=15 Mu
CCB v3.0, VCS v3.3 9

CCB & VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION:
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
under the premise of not affecting the normal growth of the improved grassland, the
grassland should be used reasonably and sustainably according to the local approved
livestock carrying capacity. For the project, totally 40,801.00 ha of degraded grassland have
been managed sustainably by grazing prohibition.
(3) Black soil beach restoration was implemented in moderately degraded grassland areas
where grass yield was less than 150 Kg/Mu and the proportion of bare patches in grassland
exceeds 40% which decreased by 21%-50% compared with the non-degraded grassland.
Reseeding grass, scientific fertilization and irrigation are carried out to restore grassland
vegetation greatly based on rodent and pest control on the "black soil beach" degraded
grassland in the project area. After reseeding the grass, the project area needs to be fenced
for 3 years to better restore grassland vegetation. Then under the premise of not affecting the
normal growth of the improved grassland, the grassland should be used reasonably and
sustainably according to the local approved livestock carrying capacity. The grass seeds
sowed were local high-quality forage such as Elymus nutans (Drooping tassel grass). In the
project, 9,896.00 ha of "black soil" degraded grassland have been reseeded grass.
In addition to these main restoration measures, the project also alleviates soil desertification and
restores grassland vegetation through grassland management measures to improve soil carbon
storage and local biodiversity, supplemented by daily management measures of other protection
projects, such as grassland fire prevention and rodent control, so as to ensure long-term
sustainable management of the project area. The project is estimated to generate GHG emission
removals of 11,698,413 tCO e in 40 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 2
292,460 tCO e. 2
The objectives of the project including:
Climate: Restore the degraded grassland ecosystem, increase grassland coverage, increase
grassland carbon sink function and reduce GHG emissions.
Community: Improve the livelihood of local herders, provide permanent and temporary job
opportunities for them, increase their income. Provide technical skills and training in sustainable
grassland management. Protect the sacred mountains (Kang Rinpoche) and holy waters (Lake
Manasarovar) widely respected by the Tibetan people which is conducive to the protection and
development of Tibet's traditional Zhangzhung culture. Zhangzhung culture is the traditional
culture of the Tibetan people, also known as the basic culture of Tibet. The traces of ancient
Zhangzhung culture run through all aspects of Tibet. From production to life, from folk custom17 to
belief, there is the shadow of Zhangzhung culture everywhere. For example, religious activities
such as offering sacrifices to mountain gods and turning mountains18 are all derived from the
Zhangzhung culture.
Biodiversity: Provide more suitable habitats for wild animals and increase local biodiversity.
17 The ancient Zhangzhung Buddha dharma occupies the supreme position in the traditional culture of ancient
Zhangzhung culture. It is the oldest Buddha Dharma in Tibet, the oldest Buddha Dharma in human history, and the
general source of all Buddha dharmas
18 A way for Tibetans to show piety
CCB v3.0, VCS v3.3 10

PROJECT DESCRIPTION

Climate Benefits
Avoid the emission of 279.290 tons of CO2e per year or 8.378.697 tons of CO2e along 30 years
