Scenario existing prior to the implementation of project activity:
The scenario existing prior to the implementation of the project activity, is electricity delivered to
the grid by the project activity that would have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-
connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources, as reflected in the
combined margin (CM) calculations described in the âTool to calculate the emission factor for an
electricity systemâ.
Baseline Scenario:
As per the applicable methodology, a Greenfield power plant is defined as âa new renewable
energy power plant that is constructed and operated at a site where no renewable energy power
plant was operated prior to the implementation of the project activityâ.
As the project activity falls under the definition of a Greenfield power plant, the baseline scenario
as per paragraph 22 of Section 5.2.1 of applied methodology is the following:
If the project activity is the installation of a Greenfield power plant, the baseline scenario is
electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by the
operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources, as
reflected in the combined margin (CM) calculations described in the âTool to calculate the
emission factor for an electricity systemâ.
Hence, pre-project scenario and baseline scenario are the same.

The project activity falls under the following Sectoral scope and Project Type:
Sectoral Scope : 01 - Energy industries (renewable / non-renewable sources)
Project Type : I - Renewable Energy Projects

1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Guohua Tongliao Kezuo Zhongqi Phase I 49.5 MW Wind Farm Project (hereinafter referred to as
âthe projectâ or project âPâ) is constructed and operated by Guohua (Tongliao) Wind Power Co.,
Ltd.
The project generates renewable power electricity by using the wind power resource, and
supplies electricity to Northeast China Power Grid (NECPG) replacing fossil fuel consumption and
thus reducing GHG (CO ) emissions. It involves installation and operation of 33 wind turbines 2
with the unit capacity of 1,500 kW and total capacity of 49.5 MW. It is estimated that the annual
generation of the proposed project will be 108,830MWh once fully operation, with a plant load
factor of 25.1%. The project lifetime is 21 years (including 1 year construction period).
The electricity currently generated by the Grid is relatively fossil fuel intensive, with a combined
margin emission factor of 1.0280 tCO /MWh. The proposed project is therefore expected to 2
reduce emissions of GHG of 111,877 tCO e per year during the first crediting period by displacing 2
electricity from NECPG.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
1.8 Ownership
As stated in the (draft) Desaâa State Forest Management Plan 2018, the Desaâa forest is owned
and managed by the government of Ethiopia, specifically by the Ethiopian Environment, Forest
and Climate change (EECCC) Commission. Accordingly, the forest has been recognized and
registered as one of the National Forest Priority areas. Following this, in 1993 the boundary of
the forest area was demarcated by the Forest Inventory and Management Planning Division of
Forest and Wildlife Conservation and Development Department. For conservation and use
purposes, a management plan was prepared in 1997 by the initiative of the Tigray Regional State
Bureau of Agriculture and Rural Development (TBoARD).
The project proponent, WeForest and the Tigray State Government, through the Tigray Regional
State Bureau of Agriculture and Rural Development (TBoARD), have signed a MoU to develop this
ARR VCS project on these lands: âMemorandum of Understanding Between Tigray Regional State
Bureau of Agriculture and Rural Development and WeForest Ethiopiaâ.
The endorsement/agreement from the federal government/EECC is currently under negotiation.
Source: Desaâa State Forest Management Plan â The Great Rift Valley Dry Afromontane Forest.
Mekelle, Tigray, April 2018 (WeForest -GIZ report 2018).
1.9 Project Start Date
Project start date was 1st January 2018. In 2018 the project activities started, including terrain
preparation, community mobilization, nursery establishment, planting and ANR tending
operations.
Records of the activities implemented by the project and the date of implementation are kept in
the project office. The planting areas are mapped and available in GIS.
1.10 Project Crediting Period
The length of the Crediting Period is 50 years and is renewable.
Start date of the Crediting Period was 1st January 2018.
The end date of the Crediting Period is 31st December 2068.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
1.16 Participation under Other GHG Programs

Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs

1.17 Other Forms of Credit
Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
The project is not included in any other emission trading program.
Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The project has not sought or not received any other form of GHG-related environmental credits.
1.18 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
The methodology applied refers to leakage due to activity shifting from inside the project area to outside
the project area as a result of the projectâs intervention. Two types of activity shifting are considered in
the methodology: cropland cultivation and grazing.
In the case of the Desaâa project area, activity shifting of cropland cultivation is not applicable. In the
baseline scenario there is no cultivation of cropland taking place inside the project area.
In Desaâa, 82% of households use the forest as a source of fodder. Grazing inside the forest is historically
one of the factors that has led to the degradation and disappearance of forest in the project area. This
was mainly caused by browsing, trampling of seedlings, and removing olive tree branches as fodder. The
importance of this driver of deforestation has however diminished in the baseline scenario for a number
of reasons.
- The major reason is that access to grass resources in the project area is arranged through a cut
and carry system, whereby grass is collected in the forest and brought to the cattle, based on
the agreements of communities for when to harvest grass.
- Zero grazing was introduced in 2006 in Tigray. By the time of the evaluation in 2011, its
adoption rate was still low. However, over the past couple of years there has been the
beginnings of an increase in zero grazing and the adoption of improved livestock, promoted by
the Tigray government. Free grazing in the Desaâa Forest is not allowed unless there is a
written permit â see forest example the Forest Proclamation1. Sometimes there are illegal
practices in some parts of the forest, mainly in the areas along the border between Tigray and

inputs.context:
CCB + VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
2 GENERAL
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (G1.2)
Zhangjiakou Zhangbei County 2017 Afforestation Project (hereafter refer to as âthe projectâ) is located in
Zhangbei county, Zhangjiakou City, Hebei Province of China. Hebei province is land locked and borders
Inner Mongolia to the northwest, Shanxi to the southwest, Liaoning to the east and Henan to the north. The
population of the province is 75.56 million. The project aims to plant native species on suitable land for
forest with low vegetative coverage rate for GHG removal whilst contributing to local sustainable
development goals.
20,750 ha (311,250Mu13) of the forest was planted on suitable lands for forest with low vegetative coverage
rate in Zhangbei county, which used to be poor sustainable ecological environment and rocky desertification.
Prior to the project, although the project area is suitable for planting trees, it lacks proper forestry
management, resulting in lower coverage of trees. Besides, there has never been any activity affecting the
local ecosystem in the project area14. By checking the afforestation plan, it was confirmed that, a small
number of trees existed in some project area before the project started, but the coverage rate was extremely
low. So, considering the lower forest coverage, Zhangbei Forestry Bureau determined that the project area
is suitable for afforestation after investigation, then the supplementary planting without disturbing the
existing trees was approved to increase the vegetative cover. All the trees were planted without disturbing
the existing trees in this report, and only the trees actually planted in this project were monitored. The
carbon credit of the original trees in the baseline scenario will not be monitored or counted in the actual net
GHG removals by sink.
The project involves Zhangbei county, with a total population of nearly 370,000. All these lands for
afforestation activities belong to the village committees. Zhangjiakou Sailin Landscaping Co., Ltd. (hereafter
referred to as Sailin Company) has been fully authorized by Zhangbei government, who represents all the
village committees, through a signed contract to act as the project proponent to implement project
management and monitoring, and to sell VCUs generated from the project so that Sailin Company
consolidate the offset resources into sizeable forestry offset projects. The implementation of the project
activity has provided 11,265 jobs for local villagers, it includes 11,200 temporary planting jobs and 65 long-
term technician jobs, among which 60 percent are women. The employment period of temporary planting
workers was during the planting period of the project, from 12 May 2017 to 15 July 2017.
13A Chinese metric unit of area, 1ha = 15 Mu.
14 Land eligibility certificate issued by Zhangbei Forestry Bureau
CCB v3.0, VCS v3.3 9

[['', 'Project Scale', None, ''], ['Project', None, '', None], ['Large project', None, 'â', None]]
[['', 'Organization name', '', 'Zhangjiakou Sailin Landscaping Co., Ltd.'], ['', 'Contact person', '', 'Chenglin Ren'], ['', 'Title', '', 'Project Manager'], ['', 'Address', '', '3rd floor, Linye Building, Chaoyang Avenue, Gaoxin District, Zhangjiakou\nCity, Hebei Province, China.'], ['', 'Telephone', '', '+86 313-5892315'], ['', 'Email', '', '1170402039@qq.com']]
CCB + VCS PROJECT DESCRIPTION
CCB Version 3, VCS Version 3
The project activity aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate change;
- Enhance biodiversity conservation by increasing the connectivity of forests;
- Improve soil and water conservation in the mountainous region and increase the forest cover;
- Generate income and job opportunities for local communities.
There is no natural renewal and reforestation before the project, and all sites were suitable lands for forest
with low vegetative coverage rate. The main objective species is Pinus sylvestris15 (Mongolica) which is
native species according to the baseline survey.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 3,900,753 tCO e 2
in 20 years from 12-May-2017 to 11-May-2037, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 195,038
tCO e. 2
2.1.2 Project Scale
2.1.3 Project Proponent (G1.1)
Zhangjiakou Sailin Landscaping Co., Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as Sailin) is a local state-owned entity,
founded in 2013 with a registered capital of US$4.28 million. The company has nearly 30 full-time
employees and more than 300 part-time staffs. Sailin Companyâs core business involves forestry
engineering construction, design and landscape engineering, etc. Sailin Company has maintained a good
relationship with local governments and villagers for years through providing them with high quality
15 The scientific name is Pinus sylvestris while the local name is Mongolica.
CCB v3.0, VCS v3.3 10

CCB & VCS Project Description Template
CCB Version 3.0, VCS Version 4.3
2 PROJECT DETAILS
2.1 Project Goals, Design and Long-Term Viability
2.1.1 Summary Description of the Project (VCS, 3.2, 3.6, 3.10, 3.11, 3.13, 3.14; CCB,
G1.2)
In February 2015, the State of HawaiÊ»i Department of Land and Natural Resources (DLNR) initiated the
Ola Hou â Restoring HawaiÊ»iâs Native Forests project. Project activities were implemented by the project
proponent in Nakula Natural Area Reserve (NAR) and Kahikinui Forest Reserve (FR) in Leeward
HaleakalÄ in the county and island of Maui (State of HawaiÊ»i), and include construction, expanding and
maintaining fence line, controlling and removing feral livestock and non-native ungulates, planting
native trees and plants, and monitoring and removing invasive species. Additional planting activity was
performed in partnership with the Leeward HaleakalÄ Watershed Restoration Partnership (LHWRP)
organization. The Nakula NAR and Kahikinui FR have been subjected to grazing by cattle, feral goats
and hogs for over 100 years12. Over this time, subject to this grazing pressure, the forest gave way to
non-native savannah grassland composed almost entirely of invasive grass species. Due to a large
population of feral ungulates and the steep terrain in this region, vegetation loss leading to erosion of
topsoil has led to further degradation and loss of carbon stocks from the project sites. By planting and
facilitating the natural regeneration via removal of feral ungulates, native woody species such as koa
(Acacia koa), Ê»ÅhiÊ»a (Metrosideros polymorpha), olopua (Nestegis sandwicensis), mamane (Sophora
chrysophylla), and pukiawe (Styphelia tameiameiae) are being restored, creating essential habitat for
rare native flora and fauna, and carbon is being sequestered. These project instances are expected to
remove an average of 287 t CO annually from the atmosphere over the project lifetime. 2
2.1.2 Audit History (VCS, 4.1)
2.1.3 Sectoral Scope and Project Type (VCS, 3.2)
12 Department of Land and Natural Resources Division of Forestry and Wildlife, 2015, Nakula Natural Area Reserve
Management Plan, State of Hawaii. Department of Land and Natural Resources Division of Forestry and Wildlife;
2021; Kahikinui State Forest Reserve Management Plan; State of Hawaii.
11

The project aims to restore native woody species and create essential habitat for rare native flora and fauna while sequestering carbon.

VCS Project Description
1.4 A brief description of the project:
The project activity is an initiative by Ms. Aishwarya Rai towards clean energy generation by
means of installation of 2 state-of-art WEGs of individual capacity 1.25 MW each, at village
Kotari near Soda Mada, District Jaisalmer in the State of Rajasthan aggregated to a total
installed capacity of 2.5MW.
The objective of the wind power project activity is to generate renewable electricity using
wind power resources and to sell the generated electricity to the State Electricity Utility
RVPNL (Rajasthan Vidyut Prasaran Nigam Limited).
The project activity is expected to generate 4899 MWh per annum. Had this amount of
electricity been produced by conventional fuel dominated power plants, it would lead to net
emission of 4439 tonnes of CO e per annum. Hence, Project Proponent (PP) decided to 2
harness renewable energy entailing to the establishment of these wind machines.
The generated electricity is being supplied to the RVPNL (herein after referred as Jaipur
DISCOM). The Rajasthan State grid forms part of the NEWNE Regional Grid of India (Since
August 2006, all regional grids except the Southern grid have been integrated and are
operating in synchronous mode, i.e. at same frequency. Consequently, the Northern, Eastern,
Western and North-Eastern grids are treated as a single grid and is being named as NEWNE
grid) which depends mainly on fossil fuels and this project activity contributes to reduced
greenhouse gas emissions caused by reliance on fossil fuels.
1.5 Project location including geographic and physical
information allowing the unique identification and
delineation of the specific extent of the project:
The geographical location of the project can be depicted from the maps as shown
below:
Figure 1: Location of Rajasthan in India

The nearest railway station is Jaisalmer Junction and the nearest airport is at Jaisalmer. The
airport is opened for flights only during tourist season.Nearest Highway is NH-15 (Jaisalmer
â Barmer).
1.6 Duration of the project activity/crediting period:
Project Start Date:
As per VCS 2007.1, the project start date shall not be before 1st January, 2002. The VCS
project activity start date is 30th September, 2004 which is the date on which the project
activity began reducing or removing GHG emissions i.e. the date of commissioning of both
the Turbines.
The VCS crediting Period will last for ten years starting from 1st April 2006 up to 31st
March 2016.
However, since the project is currently under CDM validation, it is to be noted that the
crediting period under VCS will last till the date of Registration of project under
CDM. Details are provided in section 1.13 of the PD below.
1.7 Conditions prior to project initiation:
Electricity in Rajasthan is mainly generated from the fossil fuel dominated power plants (see
section 2.4 for details). In the absence of the project activity, equivalent amount of electricity
would have been generated by the operation of fossil fuel dominated power plants. The
electricity grid is power deficit and hence the new capacity has to be added in the grid system
which would be fossil fuel dominated electricity generation.
PP has installed the project activity at a location which is a barren land and there is no
agriculture activity being undertaken at this site. There is neither any industrial activity
undertaken nor any human displacement done at the site because of the project activity.
The purpose of the present project activity is to harness renewable resources in the region,
and thereby displacing non- renewable natural resources and ultimately leading to sustainable
economic and environmental development. The project activity includes development,
design, engineering, procurement, finance, construction, operation and maintenance of wind
energy based electric generating stations supplying electricity to the RVPNL grid.
1.8 A description of how the project will achieve GHG
emission reductions and/or removal enhancements:
The project activity is a Greenfield wind power project activity with a totalled installed
capacity of 2.5 MW and is expected to generate 4899 MWh per annum. The electricity thus
generated is sold to the Jaipur DISCOM. In the absence of the project activity, equivalent
amount of electricity would have been generated by the operation of existing/proposed grid
connected fossil fuel dominated power plants. The Project activity will thus reduce the
5

2.1 Title and Reference of Methodology

2.2 Applicability of Methodology
The methodology is applicable for project activities that avoid greenhouse gases emissions by
using renewable biomass in order to generate thermal energy. In addition, the methodology is
applicable if the project generates less than 45MW of energy, which is accomplished by the
project as it generates 6.98 MW.
There are no similar registered project activities in the region of the project activity once
Sustainable Carbon - Projetos Ambientais LTDA made a research and did not find any registered
small-scale CDM Project. Therefore, the proposed project activity is not saving the non-renewable
biomass accounted for by the other registered project activities.
The utilization of firewood from areas without any kind of management cannot be considered a
renewable source of biomass, since it interferes in the carbon pools and increases the carbon
emissions to the atmosphere, turning greenhouse effect even worse. Moreover, the native wood
provided from areas without a reforestation management plan does not fit any of the options of
UNFCCC definition of renewable biomass in Annex 18, EB 2320.
Firewood coming from reforestation activities is considered renewable according to option I of the
UNFCCC definition of renewable biomass (Annex 18, EB 23), as it fits all the assumptions below:
âThe biomass is originating from land areas that are forests21 where:
(a) The land area remains a forest; and
(b) Sustainable management practices are undertaken on these land areas to ensure, in
particular, that the level of carbon stocks on these land areas does not systematically decrease
over time (carbon stocks may temporarily decrease due to harvesting); and
(c) Any national or regional forestry and nature conservation regulations are complied with.â

should apply.

model_answer: The methodology used in this project is the SOCIALCARBON methodology, which aims to improve long-term sustainability conditions by mitigating the regional culture of burning wood without sustainable management as fuel. Additionally, the project applies the small-scale methodology Category AMS-I.E.: Switch from Non-Renewable Biomass for Thermal Applications by the User - Version 09. The project also utilizes several methodological tools, including TOOL03, TOOL05, TOOL07, and TOOL11, which are approved under the Clean Development Mechanism. The methodology is applicable for project activities that avoid greenhouse gas emissions by using renewable biomass to generate thermal energy. The project generates 6.98 MW of energy, which is less than the 45 MW threshold for applicability of the methodology.

VCS Project Description Template, v4.3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Heilongjiang Zhaoyuan Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereinafter referred to
as âthe projectâ) is located in Zhaoyuan County, Daqing City, Heilongjiang Province, China. The
purpose of the project is to adopt improved agricultural land management practices to prevent
the severe soil degradation caused by pre-existing conventional tillage in local crop land.
The improved agricultural land management practices of the project focus on no-tillage on fields
evenly mulched with crushed straw for two or three years, followed by plowing or subsoiling once
and continued no-tillage for another two or three years. No-tillage can effectively reduce the
loosening of the surface soil layer and soil disturbance, reduce the loss of water and nutrients in
the soil, ensure the retention of organic matter in the soil, reduce the degree of compaction of
the tillage equipment on the tillage soil layer, and preserve appropriate space for the growth of
crops, which is convenient for ventilation and keeps the soil with good water storage capacity.
The application of no-tillage sowing has solved the problem of sand blowing in bare farmland to
a certain extent and played a role in windbreak and sand fixation. No-tillage can maximize the
protective effect of straw mulching on soil.
The project plans to implement improved agricultural land management practices in 87,479 ha
corn field in the first crediting period to increase soil organic carbon (SOC). The project proponent
not only introduced more efficient and appropriate tillage method with Zhaoyuan Agriculture and
Rural Affairs Bureau (ZARAB) to the farmers, but also provide technical training and support to
the farmers.
The scenario existing prior to the projectâs implementation is primarily conventional tillage with
straw mulching, which increase soil disturbance and the loss of soil organic matter (SOM).
During the first crediting period from 07-Apr-2021 to 06-Apr-2031, the project is expected to
generate GHG emission removals of 1,315,100 tCO e, with an average annual GHG emission 2
removal of 131,510 tCO e. 2

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
Table 1 List of titles held that make up the Rio Bravo Project.
1.10 Conditions Prior to Project Initiation
1.10.1 Climate:
Weather data collected at La Milpa Field Station on the north-western Rio Bravo Conservation and
Management Area (but outside the defined Project Area) has provided a good estimate of weather
patterns. Since conditions alter across the Rio Bravo, those in the south and east can be assessed from
observations from the weather stations at Tower Hill (near Orange Walk Town) and Spanish Lookout.
Overall the area experiences a sub-tropical moist climate with marked wet and dry seasons, dominated
by weather systems moving through the Gulf of Mexico and western Caribbean. The wet season is May â
November and the dry season is December to April. Temperatures are fairly constant across inland
northern Belize, averaging 27o C (81oF), but rainfall increases from north-west to south-east. Thus mean
annual rainfall at La Milpa over the period 1995-2005 has been 1239 mm (49â) while that at Tower Hill is
somewhat higher (1353 mm, 53â) and Spanish Lookout is higher again (1546 mm, 61â). These data
suggest that the eastern RBCMA should receive 1440-1500 mm (57-59â) per annum. The La Milpa
rainfall and that estimated for the eastern RBCMA is rather lower than those given in previous
descriptions of the area. This conforms to a slight drying trend over the past decade (Meerman &
Cherrington, 2005).

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM PDD) - Version 03  
 
CDM â Executive Board     page 42  
 
100% of the respondents have some knowledge and understandings about wind farm projects. 
100% of the respondents do not disagree with the devel opment of the Project. About 87% of them believe 
that the Project will have overall positive impacts, such as âincrease of job opportunities and incomeâ, 
âimprovement of living standardâ, on their livelihoods, while the others believe there will be little impact 
on their livelihoods or do not know the impacts.  Among the negative impacts mentioned, the main con cerns are infield occupation and plants damage 
(81%),  noise (19%), waste water and electro-magnetism pollution (6%).  The main additional comment or suggestion on the Project construction is âaccelerate the construction 
process and generation as soon as possibleâ, which reflected the support from the stakeholders. 
 
Conclusion 
 
The survey shows that the proposed project receiv es strong support from local people, which is closely 
linked to the fact that the majority of local village rs have some understandings with wind power projects. 
Most of the respondents believe that the project will have overall positive impacts on their livelihoods 
with better standard of living and reduced tariff which is quite high now. Among the negative impacts, 
the two main issues concerned are land use and envi ronmental pollution. However, as the environmental 
impact assessment demonstrates, both impacts only occur during construction period, and accompanied by mitigating measures such as enclosed operation, w aste landfill, and restored vegetation, the impacts 
will be minimized after the construction.  The survey forms are ava ilable from the company. 
 
E.3. Report on how due account was taken of any comments received:  
Focused on the negative comments received, for the in field occupation and plants damage, the project 
owner has provided compensation to the local resident s. For the noise, waste water and electro-magnetism 
pollution, as the EIA approval shown, the environmenta l protection method listed in EIA make the project 
construction minimized its negative impact on the local people and the ecological environment.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Winsome Textile Industries Ltd. (hereinafter also called as WTIL), a leading manufacturer of
textile product, started its operations in 1980 in Baddi, Himanchal Pradesh, India. WTIL has
given special stress to minimise contamination, both at pre-spinning and post-spinning stages
by adding machines like Vision Shield in Blow Room and Schlafhorst-338 with LOEPFE - 9001
(SIRO CLEANER) Contamination Control Channel at winding stage. Further addition was to
generate renewable electricity for captive consumption to minimise carbon foot print in long
term.
The project activity involves power generation from a 3.5 MW hydroelectric project based on
Manuni Khad stream, a tributary of river Beas at village Khaniara, Dharamshala, District
Kangra, Himachal Pradesh. The project activity is a run-of-river project being developed by
M/s Winsome Textile Industries Ltd. The project activity comprises 2 Numbers of Pelton
Turbines each with a generator output capacity of 1750 kW for generation of electricity.
The project was allotted to the M/s Winsome Textile Industries Ltd. on a Build, Own, Operate
and Maintain (BOOM) basis for a period of 40 years. Wheeling and Banking Agreement (PPA)
is being signed with the Himachal Pradesh State Electricity Board (HPSEB), the generated
electricity will be used for captive consumption at its manufacturing unit Baddi.
The purpose of the project activity is to produce renewable energy using hydro power for
captive consumption. In the absence of the project activity equivalent amount of electricity
would have been generated by the operation of grid connected fossil fuel based power plants.
The Project activity thus reduces the anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs)
in to the atmosphere associated with the equivalent amount of electricity generation from the
fossil fuel based grid connected power plant. The project activity has commissioned both the
turbine on 31/03/2017.
The estimated annual average and the total CO e emission reduction by the project activity 2
over the first renewable crediting period of 10 years are expected to be 17,619 tCO e and 2
176190 tCO e respectively. 2

VCS Project Description
In the absence of the project activity, an equivalent quantum of electricity would have
been generated by the fossil-fuel dominated Southern Regional Electricity Grid of
India6 generation mix. The same would in turn result in GHG emissions at the grid
end as per the carbon intensity of the above mentioned grid. This scenario has been
identified as the baseline scenario for the project activity under consideration (please
refer to section 2.4 of the VCS PD for further details).
1.8 A description of how the project will achieve GHG emission reductions
and/or removal enhancements:
The project activity under consideration entails electricity generation through wind-
mills by harnessing wind power potential, a natural and renewable source of energy.
The project is expected to generate and export of 20.965 million kWh (approx) per
year to the Southern Regional Grid of India. In the absence of the project activity, an
equivalent quantity of electricity would have been generated by the Southern Grid by
a majority of fossil-fuel fired power plants. The same would have resulted in GHG
emissions as per the carbon intensity of the grid-mix.
As per the combined margin carbon intensity of the 0.928 tCO /MWh for the 2
Southern Grid, the bundled project activity would there by result in total CO emission 2
reduction of 194560 tonnes over the crediting period of 10 years. For detailed
calculation procedure and sample calculation tables of the GHG emission reduction
quantum from the project activity, please refer to Sections 4.2, 4.3 and 4.4 of the
VCS PD.
1.9 Project technologies, products, services and the expected level of activity:
In wind energy generation, kinetic energy of wind blowing at high speeds is
converted into mechanical energy while passing through the wind-turbine. The
rotation of the turbine blades results in the rotation of the generator mounted on the
same shaft, thus generating electricity. As there are no GHG emissions associated
with wind electricity generation, the technology is widely recognized as clean
technology. An upwind7 Horizontal axis wind turbine (HAWT)8 is used in the project
activity to generate power.
o Main Tower: This is what holds the windmill up into the airflow.
o Blades: The blades are basically the sails of the system. They are flat
objects connected to the centre shaft that converts the push of the
wind into a circular motion. When the wind forces the blades to move,
it has transferred some of its energy to the rotor
6 The Indian power grid system (or the National Grid) is divided into two regional grids namely NEWNE Regional Grid
and Southern Region Grid. These regional grids have independent state Load Dispatch Centres (LDCs) that manage
flow of power in their jurisdiction. Power generated by state owned generation units and private owned generation
units is consumed by the respective states. Power generated by central sector plants is shared by all states forming
part of the grid in a fixed proportion.
7 A type of wind turbine in which the rotor faces the wind
8 A wind turbine in which the axis of the rotorâs rotation is parallel to the wind stream and the ground.
6
model_answer: There is no specific information provided in the context to determine the project sector (Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use).

ï»¿inputs.question: What is the project sector, either Renewable Energy or Forestry and Land Use?
inputs.context:
Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Anlu City within Xiaogan City, Hubei Province of China, with a total
acreage of 13,298 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this project,
which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the continuously flooded
method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded
method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition
can emit a large amount of methane (CH ) because of anaerobic decomposition, the 4
intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase
and methane emission reduction than the continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results
in not only large amount of methane (CH ) emissions but also low rice productivity by 4
replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens
the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH emission 4
can be declined by an average of 48%1 . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an
estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.32tCO e/ha for single-cropping rice is 2
expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity
is 57,504 tCO e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 575,040 tCO e during the 2 2
fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
ï· Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
ï· Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
ï· Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers;
ï· Increase in the number of individuals with improved capacity due to diversified
educational opportunities from Trainings.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The project is developed under VCS scope 14 âAgriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
(AFOLU)â with an activity category of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under

Institute. Available from: r.wassmann@irri.org

true_answer: {'project_name': 'Heishan LN1 Household Biogas Project in Jinzhou, Liaoning Province', 'project_summary': 'Heishan LN1 Household Biogas Project in Heishan Jinzhou, Liaoning Province (the project) is located in Heishan County, Jinzhou City, Liaoning Province, and P.R. China. The project is designed to construct methane recovery and utilization system for each rural household of 13,104 in total. According to the construction plan, the construction is conducted in steps and phases. 3,429 household biogas digesters installation are carried out in 2008; 5,675 household biogas digesters are installed in 2009; the remaining 4,000 biogas digesters installation are constructed in 2010. The construction is strictly based on National Standard GB/T4750-2002 for biogas digester and GB/T 3606-2001 for biogas stove. The main objective of the Project is to dispose the raw manure from pigs by anaerobic digester with a volume of 8m 3 , and to collect biogas generated during the treatment process for thermal supply which meets the cooking and water heating demands of the rural household itself by biogas stove with a thermal flow of 3.26kW each one. Before implementing the Project, all the manure would be left to decay in the uncovered anaerobic mature management system, i.e. deep pit with depth of 1meter at least; the methane generated would be emitted to the atmosphere. In addition, the heat would in the absence of the project activity be generated by stove fired with fossil fuels 1 , which is stated in the investigation report on rural household biogas utilization by Heishan County on September, 2007. The scenario in the absence of the project activity is identical to the baseline scenario.', 'project_state_province': 'Liaoning', 'project_country': 'China', 'project_latitude': 41.6, 'project_longitude': 122.08}

be reduced. With the new pigpen and latrine, less disease on human and animal will be caused
and transmitted by bacterial and virus. And all the manure is fed into the tank, which will reduce
pollution to soil and water caused by direct discharge of animal waste. Using biogas for cooking
is good for improving indoor air condition. Cooking with coal produces a large amount of SO , 2
CO and smoke, which is harmful to humanâs health. But cooking with CH ,only producing H O 4 2
and CO , is environmental friendly. In general, the environmental impacts are: 2
ï¬ GHG emissions being strongly mitigated in comparison to baseline treatment alternative;
ï¬ The environment and odour in pigpen and latrine being improved;
ï¬ Improving the indoor air condition, protecting human from SO ,CO,smoke; 2
ï¬ Avoiding pollution to soil and water caused by direct discharge of animal waste.
ï¬ Using biogas slurry instead of traditional non-fermented animal manure. The process of
generating biogas will kill many of the pathogenic bacteria found in manure that can be passed on
to humans causing intestinal diseases.
As indicated above, the proposed project can improve the rural environment and living
conditions in the project areas while reducing greenhouse gas emissions. No significant negative
environment impacts have been identified Heishan Environment Protection Bureau approved the
proposed project on December 10, 2007.
9 Published on Feb 20th 2009 by the Ministry of Environmental Protection of the Peopleâs Republic of China
85
model_answer: The start date of the crediting period for this project is either 01/01/2013 or the date of registration, whichever comes later. The length of the crediting period is 10 years.

true_answer: {'project_name': '1.5 MW Rice Husk Based Cogeneration Project at Rajaram Maize Products, Mohad, Dist. Rajnandgaon (CG), India', 'project_summary': 'Rajaram Maize Products (RMP) is operating a Starch, Glucose & Dextrose Monohydrate manufacturing plant at Village Mohad, Dist. Rajnandgaon in Chhattisgarh. In the production process, steam and electricity are required as source of energy. Before the project activity, steam was generated in two solid fuel fired boilers (One 10 TPH for regular operation and one 6 TPH as a standby) and electricity was taken from state electricity grid. Fuel for boiler was mostly coal. In order to improve electricity availability and plant productivity the plant management decided to go for captive power generation.  The plant management had mainly two options for choosing fuel for co-generation plant, viz. coal & rice husk. The management decided to go for rice husk fired co-generation plant. Thus the project activity aims at reducing the GHG emissions that would have been generated by using coal as a fuel for co-generation plant.', 'project_state_province': 'Chhattisgarh', 'project_country': 'India', 'project_latitude': 21.08, 'project_longitude': 81.08}

model_answer: Based on the given context, the methodology of this project is ACM0008 - "Abatement of methane from coal mines" (version 08.0). This methodology applies to project activities that aim for the use and/or destruction of methane extracted/obtained from a working or abandoned coal mine. The project activities include methods such as destroying methane without energy production (e.g., flaring) or using methane to produce energy (e.g., electricity, heat, vehicle fuel).
